question: Who is eligible for the Conspicuous Service Cross?

content.source_1: Conspicuous Service Cross (Australia) The Conspicuous Service Cross (CSC) is a decoration (medal) of the Australian honours system. It is awarded "for outstanding devotion to duty or outstanding achievement in the application of exceptional skills, judgment or dedication, in non-warlike situations". In October 2017, 1002 people were listed as recipients All ranks are eligible for the award. The Conspicuous Service Cross was introduced in 1989 to acknowledge outstanding achievement and performance of duty in non-warlike circumstances. Previously, there had been no option for such recognition other than using awards within the Order of Australia. Eight people have received the Conspicuous
content.source_2: Conspicuous Service Cross (New York) The Conspicuous Service Cross is a decoration for military service awarded by the State of New York. answer: All ranks are eligible for the award

The individuals who are prisoners of war, served at Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, directly participated in the Invasion of Normandy on June 6, 1944, or have been declared by the Department of Defense as killed or missing in action are eligible for the Conspicuous Service Cross
